conclusion: The separation between the two objects at any instant equals the difference in the distances they have covered up to that instant.
On a velocity-versus-time graph, distance traveled is the area under each object’s velocity curve, so the separation equals the vertical “area gap’’ between the two curves.
From the origin to time t1 object A is faster, so its area (and thus its distance) grows more quickly than B’s.
Between t1 and t2 their speeds cross and afterwards B is always faster, so B’s area starts catching up with (and eventually overtaking) A’s.

premise: The distance difference starts at zero (t = 0), increases while A is faster (0 → t1), and keeps increasing—though at a slower rate—until the instant when B has exactly made up all the extra area A accumulated earlier.
conclusion: Right at that moment the area gap stops growing and begins to shrink as B’s additional area becomes larger than A’s.
The graph shows that this “equal-area’’ crossover occurs at t2 (the point where the two equal-area triangular regions outlined by the dashed vertical line are mirrored).

premise: The graph shows that this “equal-area’’ crossover occurs at t2.
conclusion: Hence the distance between the objects reaches its maximum at t = t2.

premise: After t2 the gap diminishes, becoming zero again at t4 when both have traveled the same total distance once more.
conclusion: The objects are farthest apart at t2.
